texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you build tons of kernels every day like my team does, you look for speed improvements anywhere you can. Caching repositories, artifacts, and compiled objects makes kernel builds faster and it reduces infrastructure costs.
texts.text: When you build tons of kernels every day like my team does, you look for speed improvements anywhere you can. Caching repositories, artifacts, and compiled objects makes kernel builds faster and it reduces infrastructure costs.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We use GitLab CI in plenty of places, and that means we have a lot of gitlab-runner configurations for OpenShift (using the kubernetes executor) and AWS (using the docker-machine executor). The runner's built-in  caching makes it easy to upload and download cached items from object storage repositories like Google Cloud Storage or Amazon S3.
texts.text: We use GitLab CI in plenty of places, and that means we have a lot of gitlab-runner configurations for OpenShift (using the kubernetes executor) and AWS (using the docker-machine executor). The runner's built-in  caching makes it easy to upload and download cached items from object storage repositories like Google Cloud Storage or Amazon S3.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, there's an often overlooked feature hiding in the  configuration for the docker executor  that provides a great performance boost: mounting tmpfs inside your container. Not familiar with tmpfs? Arch Linux has a  great wiki page for tmpfs  and James Coyle has a  well-written blog post  about what makes it unique from the older ramfs.
texts.text: However, there's an often overlooked feature hiding in the  configuration for the docker executor  that provides a great performance boost: mounting tmpfs inside your container. Not familiar with tmpfs? Arch Linux has a  great wiki page for tmpfs  and James Coyle has a  well-written blog post  about what makes it unique from the older ramfs.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: RAM is much faster than your average cloud provider's block storage. It also has incredibly low latency relative to most storage media. There's a  great interactive latency page  that allows you to use a slider to travel back in time to 1990 and compare all kinds of storage performance numbers.  (It's really fun! Go drag the slider and be amazed.)
texts.text: RAM is much faster than your average cloud provider's block storage. It also has incredibly low latency relative to most storage media. There's a  great interactive latency page  that allows you to use a slider to travel back in time to 1990 and compare all kinds of storage performance numbers.  (It's really fun! Go drag the slider and be amazed.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Better yet, many cloud providers give you lots of RAM per CPU on their instances, so if your work isn't terribly memory intensive, you can use a lot of this RAM for faster storage.
texts.text: Better yet, many cloud providers give you lots of RAM per CPU on their instances, so if your work isn't terribly memory intensive, you can use a lot of this RAM for faster storage.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ⚠️  Beware of the dangers of tmpfs before adjusting your runner configuration!  See the warnings at the end of this post.
texts.text: ⚠️  Beware of the dangers of tmpfs before adjusting your runner configuration!  See the warnings at the end of this post.

texts.text: to look for its cached objects much more quickly.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Git repositories are also great things to stash on tmpfs. Big kernel repositories are usually 1.5GB to 2GB in size with tons of files. Checkouts are really fast when they're done in tmpfs.
texts.text: Git repositories are also great things to stash on tmpfs. Big kernel repositories are usually 1.5GB to 2GB in size with tons of files. Checkouts are really fast when they're done in tmpfs.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ⚠️ As mentioned earlier,  beware of the dangers of tmpfs.
texts.text: ⚠️ As mentioned earlier,  beware of the dangers of tmpfs.
